technology is enabling disruptive innovation either within the biomedical
research space or biomedical care and how these types of technologies might
change things for the better but you know when folks discuss disruptive innovation they sometimes think of it so
you know a giant wave going over an industry you have a small small guys in
a boat trying to survive technology washing over them and certainly you know
this large wave represents a host of technologies not just cloud but genomics
we've seen over the last 10 years really make precision oncology a reality cloud

healthier outcomes as well as we saw a really great case in public safety so IT
has definitely been in it for a while they've been uh you know taking their

disruption doesn't have to mean destruction it can mean surviving and

he's going to be talking about the history of his organization adopting cloud models and
and lessons learned there and then followed on quickly by dr. Caleb Kennedy from the National bone marrow registry
discussing about how to make better match outcomes healthier outcomes for patients from that registry so without

thanks angel yeah so I'll talk about being in the boat for the past seven or eight years

of interest in this base it was coming so as is kind of common in federally

in a way so we turn to eight of us so this is a kind of screenshot of the

that we built so we essentially wanted to be able to answer or help researchers

associated with particular clinical outcome or diagnosis or phenotype how
can I figure that out and you know does my set of samples differ from this healthy baseline that I just mentioned
and what's the difference why is that important so we built this tool called
nathaly that enables you to kind of bring datasets provide a little bit of
information about the analysis that you want to do and then get these outcomes it shows you the different diversity and lots of talks and outcomes charts
statistics those sort of things so this is a technical talk so I wanted to provide a little bit about the

number three putting data into Amazon s3 we have a lambda function that essentially watches that Amazon s3

we'll spin up a new easy to compute instance to do that analysis for users send sqs
notifications back to the front-end for the user to say here's your job outcome it started you can download your data

useful for the community so this is a chart that shows the daily analysis jobs
that users were doing during a beta release at the time so you see on the y-axis the number of jobs over time and
I think the key thing that I want to point out here is that you know if you average this out over a couple of months
that we had the beta release we would have had 12 analysis you know instances
jobs per user per day and in our previous model we could have you know bought enough in queue capacity to
accommodate those you know 12 on average jobs per day or maybe a little bit more but we'd have you know time when the

order of five hours on the short end maybe close to a week on the long end so if you are the 82nd person in line here
unfortunately you're going to be waiting a couple weeks if we went with that model once you're queued up and waiting

do we learn so we've had about 2,500 data analysis submissions this is a kind
of word cloud of what people tagged their analyses with and what's interesting is you see things like

seat han um so we also found that you know this number continues to grow but
in that time period we had about 500 registrations over 150 organizations this week alone I think we've had seven

used the platform that we built on ABS the key takeaway here is that it was about two or three dollars per job for a

make sure things work all that troubleshooting in time they didn't have to do so this really enabled them to kind of focus on
what are the analysis outcomes why is this meaningful as opposed to what are all the technology hurdles that I have
to get over to make this work so we also have kind of a user support system that kind of automatically ask people you

we also learned you know that over time there's entropy in any system so we had some challenges so we architected as we

we say start this job we write the output back to EFS and indicators back

Ailee microbiome analysis system so a different team within NIAID is building

also established in our internal infrastructure with the ultimate goal of saying I have a new application or a new
service or a new tool or utility I can run that internally or I can run that in
the cloud and it doesn't really matter that's a business decision and not a technic technical decision so we have
all of the same kind of services and automation happening internally that we do working on the cloud so you kind of
compile your source build into a doctor container have automated security scanning lots of other components that

logging service that also you logs information from internal servers systems and you know have lots of
monitoring and other components in this space so the kind of core concept behind
here is that we have an environment set up we can deploy new applications to
that in an automated fashion so if I am a developer I commit my code I can automatically kind of build out that
application in a container in an environment that is all fully managed within this monarch platform within
DPC's and has access to all the services and accounts that it needs so how did
the core concept here is that you know doing this in a simple way with some automation tied to it and security

we can get kind of a stable solution that we can continue to build on and that we think application developers and

so my last takeaway then is take the time to simplify what you're doing
automate as much as possible focus on security we heard that yesterday in the
kind of keynote and look to create or adopt or buy a platform that can scale I
think that's really going to go a long way in lots of your kind of use cases so
to close here I for use cases but the four lessons the key thing I want to
mention is you know it's not important to kind of just do the technology for the technology you have to kind of have

good people working on these you know kind of hard problems using these cool

thanks Nick so I'm going to just keep going I wanted to talk a little bit
about who we are as an organization so I'm going to to briefly just describe many of you probably don't know who we
are unless you've been the recipient of a bone-marrow transplant or have donated to one so we're a nonprofit organization
we've been around for about 30 years we're based in Minneapolis Minnesota we have about 950 or so employees and we're
probably best known for operating the largest and most diverse member registry
in the world so these are people who would ostensibly give bone marrow to a patient in need these patients are
typically suffering for severe blood disorders leukemia lymphomas and some other inherited diseases so what what do
we do we do a lot of things we don't actually facilitate bone-marrow transplants we operate through a global
network of partners that include transplant centers laboratories with you the genetic testing and in those terms
the most important factor for a match with good outcome is the human leukocyte
antigen so it's a system of genes that determine self from non-self so your
immune system is constantly scavenging cells in your body and looking for those that have altered themselves or are
infected with viruses and it has mechanisms lots of biological mechanisms
to eradicate those cells so that can arise in a lot of different context cancer is one of them so this is just a
graphic - just to display the most important it's not the only important factor but it is the most important
factor is that genetic matching between donor and recipient we also do a lot of work on the back end so post transplant
we're very interested in the efficacy of matching and improving matching both
with HLA as an important genetic engineers oh genome-wide so there's a
lot of information that's not captured in that small system of genes that does affect both positive and negative
outcomes for transplantation and and so just to give you a clue this is a
graphic that describes many of them HLA is part of the major histocompatibility complex and there are minor
histocompatibility antigens as well that's basically everything that's not HLA and and they they form the basis for
the positive what we call graph verses tumor or graft versus leukemia effect that's the beneficial part of matching
and transplantation but if you think about it what you're actually doing is transplanting an entire immune system
from one donor into a recipient if you don't get the matching right you can have the effect of what's called graft
versus host disease so it's a systemic effect where the donated immune system
sees everything as non-self and attacks it it's a devastating disease it happens
often 72 up to 70% of transplants have
some form of acute or chronic graft-versus-host disease so it's a
challenge and it's one that we're dedicated to solving one tool obviously that we have and a lot of others is the
rise of genomics and garden of technologies that have developed kind of
contemporaneously probably the most talked about is next-generation DNA sequencing so that enables us to get
large amounts of biomolecular data from donors and recipients from individual
cells within transplantation at a very low cost in a never dropping cost so
this is a graphic that makes it into almost every genomics talk and alongside the cost per genome curve you see
Moore's law which is the compute capacity on a single CPU what's not really discussed too much and I think
where AWS and cloud computing technologies in general are enabling is the distributed compute that a lot of
people are taking advantage of so the cost the curves will probably look a lot similar or they'd be closer together if
we were talking about distributed compute capacity which we will in just a
second nevertheless there's this glut of data and in any ever-increasing amount which
makes the interpretation of those genomic data paramount in our context
what I'm showing here is a graphic that one of my scientists put together which I thought was one of the most beautiful

just to say that well we can get a lot of genomic data and analyze it fairly quickly interpretation is still a major

and kind of parsed it out and we're learning some really interesting things about minor histocompatibility antigens
specifically in male patients with female donors because they have a Y chromosome that is inherently not-self
that can affect outcomes negatively in that case so how do we do it I'm going
to go through some use cases just a few we do it in a lot of ways everything
from the front end registry so matching donors with patients in need all the way
back to the interpretive outcomes research that I that I just described so
so we started using Amazon pretty early on about three years ago when I first joined the organization to do rapid
prototyping and development that really was the motivation for it rather than
invest a bunch of money in IT infrastructure and an internal on-premises compute that we didn't
really know we needed until we proved it out we decided to do a lot of that on the cloud we operate like I said through
a partnership of a lot of laboratories that do the genetic testing on our behalf and we add about 2,000 or so
members to the registry a day so it's not big data by most standards HLA is a
small system but we add a lot of members and the velocity of data is quite high so so
what we came up with was a global a public standard for structuring these data and metadata called
histocompatibility markup language which is a terrible name but it's an XML based
standard that we give to our ell labs they put the genetic data from donors in that standard and then they submit to us
through interfaces that we've all deployed on the cloud we have a lot of
we've used a lot of internal services of AWS again not things that we wanted to develop in-house from scratch for load
balancing for containerization for different development and production environments for validation of the data
before they enter with the registry because obviously once they're matched to a patient you didn't want to go back and say well the HLA was wrong that
would be devastating for the patient on the on the on the on that side of things and then we still once the validation
has happened we still pull the data on-premises through a firewall mostly for security reasons we're regulated by

receptive to cloud as an enabling technology they definitely want you to hold hands with them and walk the path
so that they learn one major one major benefit of this is flexibility so as we
learn more from the outcomes-based side about what is important for matching we want to add it as quickly as we can to
the genetic testing component of donors which is cheap and easy like we said but
can be a glut for our information systems if they can't react to it very quickly so HML is flexible in and of

distribution so we want to do as many searches as we can as fast as we can for

are many searches there are probably tens to hundreds of searches that actually go on for every match that is
